midgardmvc_core_node.title: Development
midgardmvc_core_node.content: <p>Midgard is a free software project, meaning that anybody is free to participate. The Midgard ecosystem provides tools for multiple programming languages and environments, meaning that there is useful functionality and contribution opportunities ranging from Linux mobile and desktop development in C, Vala or Python to web development in PHP and JavaScript.</p><h2>Development workflow</h2><p>Midgard development happens using the <a href="http://git-scm.com/">Git distributed version control system</a>. We use it following the <a href="http://whygitisbetterthanx.com/#any-workflow">integration manager workflow</a>, meaning that every Midgard project has <a href="http://github.com/midgardproject">a central "blessed" Git repository</a>, and an assigned maintainer who is the only person able to push contents to it.</p><p>This way getting started with Midgard development is easy. Simply <a href="http://help.github.com/fork-a-repo/">fork the repository</a> of the project you're interested in, make any changes you want, and then <a href="http://help.github.com/pull-requests/">send a pull request</a> to the maintainer of that project. For keeping track of these pull requests, we use <a href="http://github.com/">GitHub</a>.</p><p><img src="/mgd:attachment/7c12dfd656b911e08bd2af8d8e2700670067/view/git-workflow.png?1301041550548" title="git-workflow.png" alt="git-workflow.png?1301041550548" /><br class="GENTICS_ephemera" /></p><p>The current maintainers of main Midgard projects are:</p><ul><li><a href="/midgard2/"><b>Midgard2</b></a> and <b>MidgardCR</b>: <a href="http://github.com/piotras">Piotr Pokora</a></li><li><b>Midgard PHP5</b> bindings: <a href="http://github.com/indeyets">Alexey Zakhlestin</a></li><li><a href="/midgardmvc/"><b>Midgard MVC</b></a>: <a href="http://github.com/bergie">Henri Bergius</a></li><li><a href="/openpsa/"><b>OpenPSA</b></a>: <a href="http://github.com/flack">Andreas Flack</a></li><li><a href="/create/"><b>Midgard Create</b></a>: <a href="http://github.com/bergie">Henri Bergius</a></li></ul><p>Since Midgard development happens on GitHub, this allows you <a href="http://help.github.com/be-social/">to be social</a> and follow any Midgard projects you're interested in.</p><h4>Feature branches</h4><p>Since Git allows quick branching, it is a good idea to develop new features in their own <i>feature branches</i>. This allows you to easily switch between different feature work and the main branch of the project as needed. Alexey Zakhlestin has written a <a href="http://blog.milkfarmsoft.com/2011/03/on-feature-branches/">good introduction on feature branches</a>. </p><h3>Issue tracking</h3><p>We use the <a href="http://github.com/blog/411-github-issue-tracker">GitHub issue tracker</a> for keeping track of bug reports and enhancement requests. If you encounter an issue with any Midgard project, head to the <a href="http://github.com/midgardproject">midgardproject GitHub page</a> of that project and click on <i>Issues</i>. Before reporting a new issue it is a good idea to see if the same issue has already been reported by somebody else. If it has, then you may want to add any details about the circumstances where you encountered it as comments to that issue.</p><p>You can also vote on issues you find important.</p><h4>What makes a good bug report?</h4><ul><li><i>Be specific:</i> explain what you did, what was the expected result, and what actually happened</li><li><i>Include code:</i> if there was a particular piece of code that triggered the bug, please include the code snippet in the report</li><li><i>Backtraces:</i> if the bug is in the Midgard core libraries, then try to reproduce it running Midgard under gdb and include the backtrace </li></ul><p>Issues use <a href="http://github.github.com/github-flavored-markdown/">Markdown formatting</a> so it is easy to add links and code examples into them. You may find the <a href="http://www.chiark.greenend.org.uk/~sgtatham/bugs.html">How to report bugs effectively</a> article useful.</p><h2>Roadmap</h2><p>The Midgard project has a long history starting from late 1990s. Throughout these years the web, and other environments where Midgard is being used has changed drastically. This roadmap shows the history of the project and some of our future plans:</p><p><img src="/mgd:attachment/fd88982456bb11e0b708d98cc25ac9d9c9d9/large/midgard-roadmap.png?1301042689522" title="midgard-roadmap.png" alt="midgard-roadmap.png?1301042689522" /></p>
